items.title: Document title
items.help_text: The title of the metadata document (which may be the title of the study itself). The metadata document is the ISO 19139 metadata file (XML or JSON file) that is being generated. The "Document title" should mention the geographic scope of the data collection as well as the time period covered.

items.title: Document ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier for the metadata document. This identifier must be unique in the catalog where the metadata are intended to be published. Ideally, the identifier should also be unique globally. This is different from the "Primary ID" in section Study description / Title statement, although it is good practice to generate identifiers that establish a clear connection between these two identifiers. The Document ID could also include the metadata document version identifier. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Metadata producers

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or organization in charge of the production of the ISO 19139 metadata. If the name of individuals cannot be provided due to an organization’s data protection rules, the title of the person, or an anonymized identifier, can be provided (or this field can be left blank if no other option is available).

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: The initials of the person, or the abbreviation of the organization’s name mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The specific role of the person or organization mentioned in "Name" in the production of the DDI metadata.

items.help_text: The metadata producer is the person or organization with the financial and/or administrative responsibility for the processes whereby the metadata document was created. This is a "Recommended" element. For catalog administration purposes, information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful.

items.title: Production date
items.help_text: The date the ISO 19139 metadata document was produced (not the date it was distributed or archived), preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYY-MM). A validation rule can be set in user templates to enforce a date format. This is a "Recommended" element, as information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful for catalog administration purposes

items.title: Version
items.help_text: Documenting a dataset is not a trivial exercise. It may happen that, having identified errors or gaps in a DDI document, or after receiving suggestions for improvement or additional input, the DDI metadata are modified. The "Version" element and the elements "Version date", "Version responsibility", and "Version notes" describe the version of the metadata document. The "Version" element is used to enter the label of the version of the metadata document, also known as release or edition. For example, "Version 1.1" or "v1.1".

items.title: Primary ID
items.help_text: The "Primary ID" (also referred to as IDNO) is a unique identification number used to identify the study (geographic dataset or service). A unique identifier is required for cataloguing purpose, so this element is declared as "Required". The identifier will allow users to cite the study properly. The identifier must be unique within the catalog. Ideally, it should also be globally unique; the recommended option is to obtain a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the study. Alternatively, the "Primary ID" can be constructed by an organization using a consistent scheme. The identifier should not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Language
items.help_text: Main language used in the metadata description.

items.title: Character set
items.help_text: The character set encoding used in the dataset.

items.title: Parent identifier
items.help_text: A geographic data resource can be a subset of a larger dataset. For example, an aquatic species distribution map can be part of a data collection covering all species, or the 2010 population census dataset of a country can be part of a dataset that includes all population censuses for that country since 1900. In such case, the parent identifier metadata element can be used to identify this higher-level resource. As for the fileIdentifier, the parentIdentifier must be a unique identifier persistent in time. In a data catalog, a parentIdentifier will allow the user to move from one dataset to another. The parentIdentifier is generally applied to datasets, although it may in some cases be used in data services descriptions.

items.title: Hierarchy level
items.help_text: The hierarchy level defines the scope of the resource. It indicates whether the resource is a collection, a dataset, a series, a service, or another type of resource. The ISO 19139 provides a controlled vocabulary for this element. It is recommended but not mandatory to make use of it. The most relevant levels for the purpose of cataloguing geographic data and services are dataset (for both raster and vector data), service (a capability which a service provider entity makes available to a service user entity through a set of interfaces that define a behavior), and series. Series will be used when the data represent an ordered succession, in time or in space; this will typically apply to time series, but it can also be used to describe other types of series (e.g., a series of ocean water temperatures collected at a succession of depths).

items.title: Hierarchy level name
items.help_text: The "hierarchy level name" provides an alternative to describe hierarchy levels, using free text instead of a controlled vocabulary. The use of "hierarchy level" is preferred to the use of "hierarchy level name".

items.title: Contact

props.title: Person name
props.help_text: Name of the individual

props.title: Organisation name
props.help_text: Name of the organization

props.title: Position
props.help_text: Position of the individual in the organization

props.title: Role
props.help_text: Role of the person/organization. A recommended controlled vocabulary is provided by ISO 19139

props.title: Name
props.help_text: Name of the online resource. In case of a geographic standard data services, this should be filled with the identifier of the resource as published in the service. Example, for an OGC Web Map Service (WMS), we will use the layer name.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: Description of the online resource

props.title: URL
props.help_text: URL of the online resource. In case of a geographic standard data services, only the base URL should be provided, without any service parameter.

props.title: Protocol
props.help_text: Web protocol used to get the resource, e.g., FTP, HTTP. In case of a basic HTTP, the ISO 19139 suggests the value ‘WWW:LINK-1.0-http–link’. For geographic standard data services, it is recommended to fill this element with the appropriate protocol identifier. For an OGC Web Map Service (WMS) link for example, use ‘OGC:WMS-1.1.0-http-get-map’

props.title: Function
props.help_text: Function (purpose) of the online resource.

items.help_text: The ISO 19139 specification provides a structured set of metadata elements to describe a contact. A contact is the party (person or organization) responsible for a specific task. The following set of elements can be used to describe a contact:

items.title: Date stamp
items.help_text: Date and time when the metadata record was created or updated. Requires an extended ISO 8601 formatted combined UTC date and time string (2009-11-17T10:00:00).

items.title: Metadata standard name
items.help_text:
The name of the geographic metadata standard used to describe the resource. The recommended values are:
- in the case of vector dataset metadata: ISO 19115 Geographic information - Metadata
- in the case of grid/imagery dataset metadata: ISO 19115-2 Geographic Information - Metadata Part 2 Extensions for imagery and gridded data
- in the case of service metadata: ISO 19119 Geographic information - Services

items.title: Metadata standard version
items.help_text:
The version of the metadata standard being used. It is good practice to enter the standard’s inception/revision year. ISO standards are revised with an average periodicity of 10-year. Although the ISO TC211 geographic information metadata standards have been reviewed, it is still accepted to refer to the original version of the standard as many information systems/catalogs still make use of that version. The recommended values are:
- in the case of vector dataset metadata: ISO 19115:2003
- in the case of grid/imagery dataset metadata: ISO 19115-2:2009
- in the case of service metadata: ISO 19119:2005

items.title: Dataset URI
items.help_text: A unique resource identifier for the dataset, such as a web link that uniquely identifies the dataset. The use of a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) is recommended.

items.title: Identification
items.help_text: Keywords contribute significantly to making a resource more discoverable. Entering a list of relevant keywords is therefore highly recommended. Keywords can, but do not have to be selected from a controlled vocabulary (thesaurus).

items.title: Title
items.help_text: Title of the resource

items.title: Alternate title
items.help_text: An alternate title (if applicable)

items.title: Date

props.title: Date
props.help_text: The date, in ISO format.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of date should be provided, and selected from the controlled vocabulary proposed by the ISO 19139.

items.help_text: Date(s) associated to a resource. This may include different types of dates.

items.title: Edition
items.help_text: Edition of the resource.

items.title: Edition date
items.help_text: Edition date, in ISO format.

items.title: Identifier authority
items.help_text: A unique persistent identifier for the metadata. If a DOI is available for the resource, the DOI should be entered here. The same fileIdentifier should be used if no other persistent identifier is available.

items.title: Responsible party
items.help_text: Contact(s)/party(ies) responsible for the resource.

items.title: Presentation form
items.help_text: Form in which the resource is made available. The ISO 19139 recommends a controlled vocabulary. For a geospatial dataset or web-layer, the value mapDigital will be preferred.

items.title: Series name
items.help_text: A description of the series, in case the resource is part of a series.

items.title: Series issue
items.help_text: A description of the series, in case the resource is part of a series.

items.title: Series page
items.help_text: A description of the series, in case the resource is part of a series.

items.title: Other citation details
items.help_text: Any other citation details to specify.

items.title: Collective title
items.help_text: A title in case the resource is part of a broader resource (e.g., data collection).

items.title: ISBN
items.help_text: International Standard Book Number (ISBN); an international standard identification number for uniquely identifying publications that are not intended to continue indefinitely.

items.title: ISSN
items.help_text: International Standard Serial Number (ISSN); an international standard for serial publications.

props.title: Frequency
props.help_text: Maintenance and update frequency

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Keywords type. The ISO 19139 provides a recommended controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Keyword
props.help_text: The keyword itself. When possible, existing vocabularies should be preferred to writing free-text keywords. An example of global vocabulary is the Global Change Master Directory that could be a valuable source to reference data domains / disciplines, or the UNESCO Thesaurus.

props.title: Thesaurus name
props.help_text: A reference to a thesaurus (if applicable) from which the keywords are extracted. The thesaurus itself should then be documented as a citation.

items.title: Legal and security constraints

props.title: Access constraints
props.help_text: Legal access constraints. The ISO 19139 provides a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Use constraints
props.help_text: Use constraints. To be entered as free text. Filling this element will depend on the resource that is described. As best practice recommended to fill this element, this is where terms of use, disclaimers, preferred citation or* even data limitations can be captured

props.title: Other constraints
props.help_text: Any other legal constraints related to the resource.

props.title: Classification
props.help_text: Classification code. The ISO 19139 provides a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Classification system
props.help_text: Information on the system used to classify the information. Organizations may have their own system to classify the information.

props.title: Description of the classification
props.help_text: Additional free-text description of the classification.

props.title: Note on constraints
props.help_text: Note to users (free text)

items.help_text: The constraints common set of elements will be used to document legal and security constraints associated with the documented dataset or data service. Both types of constraints have one property in common, useLimitation, used to describe the use limitation(s) as free text.

items.title: Geographic element

props.title: Bounding box
West bound longitude
props.help_text: West

props.title: East bound longitude
props.help_text: East

props.title: South bound latitude
props.help_text: South

props.title: North bound latitude
props.help_text: North
providing the coordinates bounding the limits of the dataset, by means of four properties: South bound longitude, West bound longitude, North bound longitude, East bound longitude

items.help_text: Spatial (horizontal) extent element. This can be defined either with a Bounding Box (recommended); or using Geographic Description - free text that defines the area covered. When the dataset covers one or more countries, it is recommended to enter the country names in this element, as it can then be used in data catalogs for filtering by geography.

items.title: Temporal element

props.title: Extent
props.help_text: Depending on the temporal characteristics of the dataset, this will consist in a TimePeriod (made of a beginPosition and endPosition) or a TimeInstant (made of a single timePosition) referencing date/time information according to ISO 8601.

items.help_text: Temporal extent element. Depending on the temporal characteristics of the dataset, this will consist in a Time period (made of a begin position and end position) or a time instant (made of a single time position) referencing date/time information according to ISO 8601.

items.title: Vertical element
items.help_text: Spatial (vertical) extent element, providing two properties: minimum value, maximum value and vertical CRS (reference to the vertical coordinate reference system)

items.title: Spatial representation type
items.help_text: The spatial representation type of the dataset. Values should be selected from the following controlled vocabulary: {vector, grid, textTable, tin, stereoModel, video}

items.title: Spatial resolution
items.help_text: The spatial resolution of the data as numeric value associated to a unit of measure.

props.title: Amendment number
props.help_text: Format version amendment number

items.title: Service type
items.help_text: The type of service (as free text),eg. OGC:WMS

items.title: Service type version
items.help_text: The version of the service e.g. 1.3.0

props.title: Topology level
props.help_text: Topology level is the type of topology used in the vector spatial dataset. The ISO 19139 provides a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of geometry handled. A controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Count
props.help_text: The number (count) of geometries in the dataset.

props.title: Grid data
Number of dimensions
props.help_text: Number of dimensions in the grid.

props.title: Axis dimension properties
Name
props.help_text:
The name of the dimension type: the ISO 19139 provides a controlled vocabulary with the following options: row, column, vertical, track, crossTrack, line, sample, and time. These options represent the following:
- row: ordinate (y) axis
- column: abscissa (x) axis
- vertical: vertical (z) axis
- track: along the direction of motion of the scan point
- crossTrack: perpendicular to the direction of motion of the scan point
- line: scan line of a sensor
- sample: element along a scan line
- time: duration

props.title: Size
props.help_text: The length of the dimension.

props.title: Resolution
props.help_text:
The dimension resolution: a resolution number associated to a unit of measurement. This is the resolution of the grid cell dimension. For example:

for longitude/latitude dimensions, and a grid at 1deg x 5deg, the ‘row’ dimension will have a resolution of 1 deg and the ‘column’ dimension will have a resolution of 5 deg
for a “vertical” dimension, this will represent the elevation step. For example, the vertical resolution of the mean Ozone concentration between 40m and 50m altitude at a location of longitude x/ latitude y would be 10 m.
similar: in case of a spatial-temporal grid, the “time” resolution will represent the time lag (e.g., 1 year, 1 month, 1 week, etc.) between two measures.
A list of each dimension including, for each dimension, the name, size, and resolution.

props.title: Cell geometry
props.help_text:
The type of geometry used for grid cells. Possible values are: point, area, voxel, and stratum. Most “grids” are commonly area-based, but in principle a grid goes beyond this and the grid cells can target a point, an area, or a volume.
- point: each cell represents a point
- area: each cell represents an area
- voxel: each cell represents a volumetric measurement on a regular grid in a three dimensional space
- stratum: height range for a single point vertical profile
The grid spatial representation describes gridded (raster) data using three properties.

items.title: Reference system
items.help_text:
The reference system(s) typically (but not necessarily) applies to the geographic reference system of the dataset. Multiple reference systems can be listed if a dataset is distributed with different spatial reference systems. This block of elements may also apply to service metadata. A spatial web-service may support several map projections / geographic coordinate reference systems.

A reference system is defined by two properties:
- the identifier of the reference system. The recommended practice is to use to the Spatial Reference IDentifier (SRID) number. For example, the SRID of the World Geodetic System (WGS 84) is 4326.
- the code space of the source authority providing the SRID. The best practice is to use the EPSG authority code EPSG (as most of geographic reference systems are registered in it). Codes from other authorities can be used to define ad-hoc projections, for example:
ESRI:54012 (Eckert IV equal area projection)
EPSG:4326 (World Geodetic System 84 - aka WGS84), the system used for GPS
EPSG:3857 (Web Mercator / Pseudo-Mercator) - widely used for map visualization from web map tile providers.

The main reference system registry is EPSG, which provides a “search by name” tool for users who need to find a SRID (global or local/country-specific). Other websites reference geographic systems, but are not authoritative sources including http://epsg.io/ and https://spatialreference.org/ The advantage of these sites is that they go beyond the EPSG registry, and handle other specific registries given by providers like ESRI.

The following ESRI projections could be relevant, in particular those in support of world equal-area projected maps (maps conserving area proportions):
- ESRI:54012 (Eckert IV)
- ESRI:54009 (Mollweide)
- ESRI:54030 (Robinson)

props.title: Compliance code
props.help_text: Boolean

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation

props.title: Identifier authority
props.help_text: Identifier

props.title: Dimension
props.help_text: List of coverage dimensions. Each dimension can be defined by a name and a type. For the type, a good practice is to rely on primitive data types defined in the XML Schema https://www.w3.org/2009/XMLSchema/XMLSchema.xsd

items.title: Distribution format

props.title: Amendment number
props.help_text: Format version amendment number

items.help_text: Format(s) definitions.

items.title: Distributor
items.help_text: Contact(s) in charge of the resource distribution.

props.title: Scope
props.help_text: Scope / hierarchy level targeted by the data quality information section. The ISO 19139 recommends the use of a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Report
Name of measure
props.help_text: One or more measure names used for the data quality report.

props.title: Measure identification
props.help_text: Identification of the measure, using a unique identifier (if applicable).

props.title: Measure description
props.help_text: A description of the measure.

props.title: Evaluation method type
props.help_text: Type of evaluation method. The ISO 19139 recommends the use of a controlled vocabulary with the following options: directInternal, directExternal, indirect.

props.title: Evaluation method description
props.help_text: Description of the evaluation method.

props.title: Title
props.help_text: Citation of the evaluation procedure (as citation element).

props.title: Date
Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation
Date time when the report was established.

props.title: Issue
props.help_text: Identification of the issue

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation

props.title: Issue
props.help_text: Identification of the issue

A report describes the result of an assessment of the conformance (or not) of a resource to consistency rules. The result is the main component of a report, which can be described with a list of sub-elements.

props.title: Lineage
props.help_text: The lineage provides a structured solution to describe the work flow that led to the production of the data/service, defined by a general statement of the work flow performed, and a sequence of process steps performed.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: Description of the process step performed.

props.title: Rationale
props.help_text: Rationale of the process step.

props.title: Date
props.help_text: Date of the processing.

props.title: Processor
props.help_text: Contact(s) acting as processor(s) for the target step.

props.title: Source
Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation

props.title: Issue
props.help_text: Identification of the series issue
Source(s) used for the process step. Each source can have a description and a citation (as citation element).

items.title: Metadata maintenance and update frequency
items.help_text: The metadata maintenance and update frequency elements provide information on the maintenance of the metadata including the frequency of updates. This is a free text element. The information should be chosen from values recommended by the ISO 19139 controlled vocabulary with the following options: continual, daily, weekly, fortnightly, monthly, quarterly, biannually, annually, asNeeded, irregular, notPlanned, unknown.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation

props.title: Issue
props.help_text: Identification of the series issue

props.title: Type
props.help_text: Date type e.g. publication, revision, creation

items.title: Name
items.help_text: Name of the feature catalogue.

items.title: Scope
items.help_text: Subject domain(s) of feature types defined in this feature catalogue.

items.title: Fields of application
items.help_text: One or more fields of applications for this feature catalogue.

items.title: Version number
items.help_text: Version number of this feature catalogue, which may include both a major version number or letter and a sequence of minor release numbers or letters, such as ‘3.2.4a.’ The format of this attribute may differ between cataloguing authorities.

items.title: Version date
items.help_text: Version date in ISO 8601 format.

items.title: Individual name
items.help_text: The responsible party (person) in charge of the feature catalogue production.

items.title: Organisation name
items.help_text: The responsible party (organization) in charge of the feature catalogue production.

items.title: Functional language
items.help_text: Formal functional language in which the feature operation formal definition occurs in this feature catalogue.

items.title: Feature type

props.title: Type name
props.help_text: Text string that uniquely identifies this feature type within the feature catalogue that contains this feature type.

props.title: Definition
props.help_text: Definition of the feature type.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: Code that uniquely identifies this feature type within the feature catalogue that contains this feature type.

props.title: Is abstract
props.help_text: Indicates if the feature type is abstract or not

props.title: Aliases
props.help_text: One or more aliases as equivalent names of the feature type.

props.title: Carrier of characteristics
Member name
props.help_text: Name of the property member of the feature type.

props.title: Definition
props.help_text: Definition of the property member.

props.title: Cardinality lower
props.help_text: Definition of the member type cardinality. The cardinality is set of two properties: lower cardinality (lower) and upper cardinality (upper). For simple tabular datasets, the cardinality will be 1-1. Multiple cardinalities (eg. 1-N, N-N) apply particularly to feature catalogues/types that describe relational databases.

props.title: Cardinality upper
props.help_text: Definition of the member type cardinality. The cardinality is set of two properties: lower cardinality (lower) and upper cardinality (upper). For simple tabular datasets, the cardinality will be 1-1. Multiple cardinalities (eg. 1-N, N-N) apply particularly to feature catalogues/types that describe relational databases.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: Code for the attribute member of the feature type. Corresponds to the actual column name in an attributes table.

props.title: Measurement unit
props.help_text: Measurement unit of the values (in case of the feature member corresponds to a measurable variable)

props.title: Value type
props.help_text: Type of value. A good practice is to rely on primitive data types defined in the XML Schema https://www.w3.org/2009/XMLSchema/XMLSchema.xsd

props.title: Listed values
props.help_text: List of controlled value(s) used in the attribute member. Each value corresponds to an object compound by 1) a label, 2) a code (as contained in the dataset), 3) a definition. This element will be used when the feature member relates to reference datasets, such as code lists or registers. e.g., list of countries, land cover types, etc.

Feature attribute(s) / column(s) definitions. Each feature attribute, i.e. column that is a member of the vector data structure is defined as carrier of characteristics. Each set of characteristics can be defined with a set of properties.

items.help_text: One or more feature type(s) defined in the Feature catalogue. The definition of several feature types can be considered when targeting various forms of a dataset (e.g., simplified vs. complete set of attributes, raw vs. aggregated, etc.) In practice, a simple ISO 19110 feature catalogue will reference one feature type describing the unique dataset structure.
